Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of nitrogen-containing carbon nanosheets synthesized from Acorus Calamus. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Synthesized carbon nanoparticles from Acorus Calamus: (a) XRD, (b) FTIR, and (c) Raman analyses. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of C-750: (a) survey scan; core level spectra of (b) C1s, (c) N1s, and (d) O1s. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) TEM image, (b) magnified TEM image, (c) HRTEM image and (d) SAED pattern of C-450 sample. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) TEM image, (b) magnified TEM image, (c) HRTEM image, and (d) SAED pattern of C-750 sample. Fig 5 Fig. 6 FESEM analysis of (a) C-450, (b) C-750, and (c) EDAX pattern of C-750. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm carried at 77 K: (a) C-750, (b) corresponding pore size distribution curve; (c) NDBC and inset figure is corresponding pore size distribution. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a, b) CV of the BC and NDBC at various scan rates; (c) current vs. scan rate profile of NDBC; GCD profile: (d) BC and (e) NDBC at different applied current densities. Fig 8 Fig. 9 (a, b) CV plot of C-450 and C-750 at various scan rates; (c) current vs. scan rate profile of C-750; GCD profile: (d) C-450 and (e) C-750 at different applied current densities. Modern society's biggest challenges are affordable, clean energy production and storage. Thus, recent research aims at the discovery of novel electrode materials for enhanced energy production and storage. Herein, nitrogen-implanted carbon particles were synthesized for the first time from the Acorus Calamus for the symmetric supercapacitor application. The KOH-activated carbon particles at 750 °C (C-750) under a nitrogen atmosphere revealed the better structural, textural, morphological, and electrochemical performance. The BET analysis confirmed that the C-750 carbon nanoparticles tremendously enhanced the surface area of about 3551.07 m2/g. Further, the pore size and pore volume were obtained from BJH analysis that showed 3.70 nm and 0.51 cc/g, respectively. The high surface area along with the mesoporous nature of the C-750 sample effectively enhanced the specific capacitance to 354.44 Fg−1 at 1 Ag−1 using a 6 M KOH electrolytic solution. Further, the enhancement of energy and power density of the C-750 was observed at about 47.2 Whkg−1 and 16,000 Wkg−1, respectively. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acorus Calamus Hydrothermal Carbonization Porous structures Electrochemical double layer capacitance Supercapacitor Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past two decades, the pace of industrialization, the world's population, and the quality of people's lifestyles have all greatly increased. Additionally, frontier research in the areas of energy generation and energy storage has advanced to help people live more comfortably. As it is well-known that world economic development and a sustainable environment are the two fundamental pillars of the modern world which depend on energy production and energy storage [1]. Still now, fuel, coal, and radioactive materials are used as the major energy sources which emit greenhouse gasses into the environment and cause global warming. Hence, there is an urge in finding an alternative way and/or materials for the energy storage devices to achieve a high-energy and long-running time [2,3]. There are several efforts made in the field of electrochemistry, specifically for energy storage and conversion technologies, such as lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) [3], supercapacitors (SC) [4], fuel cells [5], metal-air batteries [6]. Among them, supercapacitors have attracted the features to store energy in the form of electrochemical due to their superior power density and extended cycle life [7,8]. The power hybrid electric vehicles and electronic equipment quickly due to their excellent storage property [9]. The SC can be categorized into two major types, (i) electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLC) and (ii) Pseudocapacitors (PC). While a pseudocapacitor stores charges on the surface of an electrode as a result of faradaic reactions, an EDLC process stores charges at the interface of an electrode and electrolyte [10]. The development of advanced energy storage technologies has gained much attention in the energy industrial sectors thereby promoting huge active research in the area of storage devices [11]. The SC is used to store the charges by ion adsorption or electrochemical reaction at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte which has significant interest due to its high power density, fast charging, and longevity [12–14]. To enhance the functionality and energy storage capacity of supercapacitors, new materials have been discovered and these include metal oxides and composites, polymers, and carbon-based materials [15]. However, the new robust carbon-based materials at reasonable costs, conductivity, and chemical stability are important factor and it is playing a crucial role in storage devices and energy production, but it is a challenging task [16,17]. In recent years, different carbon-based materials from natural sources like aloe vera, lignin, human hair, watermelon, scrap waste tires, jackfruit, soybean, corncobs, wheat straws, teakwood sawdust have been researched to improve the energy storage capacity and cyclic stability [18,19]. Biomass and natural plant-based carbon materials have gotten a lot of attention because they are nontoxic, come from renewable sources, are cheap, and can have heteroatoms implanted from natural sources. This increases the surface area and gives the material a hierarchical pore architecture. So, electrode materials made from carbon enhance the charge storage and therefore increases the SC performance [20]. These newly developed carbon and carbon-based materials need to be chemically activated or activated by steam in the presence of reagents such as NaOH, KOH, ZnCl2, and H3PO4 to produce a rough surface along with a porous structure and, as a result, increase the surface area of the carbon particles. . Among the different reagents used, KOH is widely used because K + ions effectually etch the carbon surface and also aids in achieving the porous structures thereby enhancing the surface area. Therefore, KOH activation effectively improves the surface area, pore structure, pore volume, and electrical conductivity of the carbon materials, thereby, enhances the charge storage capacity of supercapacitors [21]. In this study, for the first time, a large-scale, easy, cost-effective, template-free technique was used to synthesize nitrogen-implanted carbon from Acorus Calamus for high-performance symmetry supercapacitors using the hydrothermal and carbonization method. The Acarus Calamus consists of phytochemical constituents such as beta-asarone and alpha-asarone, saponins, lectins, sesquiterpenoids, lignans, and steroids [22]; which are highly supportive in producing the carbon particles during the carbonization process. Acorus Calamus has traditionally been used to cure gastrointestinal problems and pain, and its aroma makes calamus essential oil valuable in the perfume industry. [22]. The prime advantages of the present investigation focus on the facile and effective synthetic route to obtain a high yield. Further, inexpensive sustainable materials are used as a precursor to obtain carbon particles and to improve the surface-to-volume ratio. Additionally, the enhancement of rough surface area and porosity will be formed without involving any templates. Finally, the obtained carbon particles are used as the active electrode materials in the fabrication of supercapacitors. Thus, the current study will provide a new opportunity to synthesize large-scale production as well as mesoporous carbon nanomaterials from biomass for boosting energy storage applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and chemicals Acorus Calamus was collected from the local market in kelampakkam, Chennai, the nearest SSN College of Engineering. Potassium hydroxide (KOH), ammonia solution (NH4OH), hydrochloric acid (HCL), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMB), carbon black, and poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) were purchased from SRL chemicals and used for fabricating the carbon-based materials, and nickel foam was purchased from Wee suppliers and used as a substrate (resistance and thickness were about 69.3 nΩ-m (20 °C) and 1.6 mm respectively). No additional purification was performed before using any of the compounds. 2.2 Synthesis method Fig. 1 represents the graphic of the synthesis of carbon nanosheets derived from Acorus Calamus and nitrogen-implanted carbon nanoparticles were synthesized by both hydrothermal and carbonization (under N2 atmosphere) processes. In general, activated carbon was synthesized through the carbonization process under the inert atmosphere. During this process, the cost of the instrument and inert gas is relatively high. Hence, to avoid the synthesis cost different types of synthesis methods will be recommended to prepare the activated carbon particles. Thus, in the present work, both carbonization and hydrothermal method were followed to prepare the activated carbon from Acorus Calamus. First, in the hydrothermal method, Acorus Calamus was washed with distilled water and then dried at 70 °C for 24 h in a hot air oven. Then the dried Acorus Calamus burned at room temperature using an oil lamp. The obtained carbon particles were separated using sieves and then washed with 1 M of HCl solution, followed by distilled water and ethanol until the pH value reaches to be 7, then the materials are subjected to be dried at 70 °C for 24 h in a hot air oven. The collected carbon particles were named burned carbon (BC) for our reference. Further, the nitrogen-implanted carbon particles were synthesized by the hydrothermal method. During the hydrothermal process, 0.2 g of BC was mixed with 120 mL of distilled water and sonicated for 1 h. Subsequently, 20 mL of ammonia solution was added and then sonicated for 15 min. Then the solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 48 h (5 °C/min). The obtained carbon particles were washed several times with distilled water and ethanol and dried at 70 °C for 24 h. The obtained carbon particle was named nitrogen-doped burned carbon (NDBC) for our reference. On the other hand, the carbon-based particles were synthesized using Acorus Calamus through the carbonization process in a tubular furnace under the nitrogen flow. Acorus Calamus was washed with 1 M HCl and deionized water to remove any impurities present in the prepared material. Subsequently, Acorus Calamus was cut into small pieces and dried at 80 °C for 6 h and pre-heated at 200 °C for 12 h. Then the carbonization process was carried out in a tubular furnace under a nitrogen atmosphere at 450 °C for 4 h (5 °C/min). The collected carbon particles were mixed with KOH (stoichiometric ratio of 1:3) and carbonized at 750 °C for 4 h (5 °C/min) in a tubular furnace under a nitrogen atmosphere. The chemical activation process was carried out for carbon sources using KOH as the activating reagent is very promising because of its lower activation temperature and higher yields, and well-defined micropore size distribution than the other activating reagent. The obtained activated carbon particles were washed several times with distilled water and ethanol. Finally, the obtained activated carbon nanoparticles were dried at 80 °C overnight in a vacuum oven. The synthesized carbon at 450 °C and activated carbon at 750 °C were named C-450 and C-750, respectively. All the synthesized catalysts are characterized by various physicochemical techniques such as XRD, FT-IR, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, the procedure and the instruments used were given in the supporting information. On the other hand, the electrochemical characterizations of the synthesized catalysts are performed in a traditional three-electrode system, in which nickel foam coated with the electrocatalyst served as a working electrode, Pt electrode serves as counter electrode and Ag/AgCl is used as a reference electrode. The working electrode was prepared in the form of the slurry and then coated on the nickel foam. the nickel foam-coated working electrode is then used for characterizing various electrochemical measurements such as cyclic voltammetry, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy charge-discharge curves, etc. the detailed information on electrode preparation and electrochemical characterization parameters are given in the supporting information [23–27]. The frequency range was fixed as 10 Hz to 100,000 Hz; whereas in the DC parameters, the potential was maintained as 0.005 V. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structural analysis The carbonization process was carried out at two temperatures of 450 °and 750 °C for 4 h. During the carbonization of 450 °C for 4 h, the source material of Acorus Calamus was burned and then formed carbon particles. Further, the obtained carbon particles were activated using KOH at 750 °C for 4 h. Thereby, crystallite size and surface area of the carbon particles were effectively improved than that of other samples. Hence, in the present work, the KOH-activated sample of C-750 reveals better activity. The XRD pattern of BC, NDBC, C-450, and C-750 have presented in Fig. 2 a. The XRD analysis shows peaks at 2θ=25.0° and 2θ=43.0° related to the (002) and (100) planes respectively which confirmed that the synthesized carbon particles are in crystalline nature. The NDBC carbon particles showed a slightly suppressed XRD peak intensity than the BC this may be due to the crystallization process that occurred during the hydrothermal process. The XRD peak of both the C-450 and C-750 samples showed wide diffraction which revealed that the synthesized carbon is a well-crystalline arrangement [28]. The C-750 peak is relatively suppressed after the KOH etching process, the reason for the reduced intensity may be due to the formation of defects in the carbon nanosheets. The Debye-Scherrer formula D = Kλ/βcosθ [29,30] was used to determine the crystallite size from the (002) plane which revealed that the crystallite size of BC is 1.481 nm for BC and 1.012 nm for NDBC. The decrease in crystallite size might be due to the influence of the hydrothermal treatment and/or might be due to the removal of unreacted carbon particles and the effect of ammonia on the carbons. The crystallite size of C-450 is found to be 2.183 nm whereas the crystallite size of C-750 is found to be a decreased value of 1.053 nm. The XRD analysis confirmed that the nitrogen-implanted C-750 effectively modified the crystallite size more than that of the as-synthesized C-450. The FTIR spectra of the BC, NDBC, C-450, and C-750 are presented in Fig. 2b. The C-450 and C-750 showed the characteristic stretching frequencies at 3434, 2265, 1754, 1570, 1439, 956, and 626 are related to O−H, C−H, C=O, C=C, −C−C, C−N and −C=C functional groups, respectively [31–34]. Further, the wide peak observed at 954 cm−1 possesses a CN band which confirmed the nitrogen implanted in the carbon structure [31,32]. The FTIR spectra of the BC and NDBC showed less intensity than that of C-450 and C-750. Hence, it is confirmed that the C-450 and C-750 synthesized through the carbonization process under the nitrogen atmosphere effectively increase the functional groups. The Raman spectra of BC, NDBC, C-450, and C-750 are presented in Fig. 2c. The synthesized carbon particles showed the peaks at 1589 and 1342 cm−1are related to the G band (sp2 carbon with in-plane E2g) and the D band (A1g symmetry), respectively [32]. The Raman spectra of BC, NDBC, C-450, and C-750 showed the ID/IG ratio is 1.0, 1.12, 0.97, and 1.32, respectively for C-450, C-750, BC, and NDBC. However, the C-750 sample showed a high ID/IG ratio of about 1.32 which confirmed the presence of a high degree of defect sites that effectively enhanced the charge storage capacity. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of C-750 is presented in Fig. 3 . The survey scan of C-750 (Fig. 3a) showed the presence of carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen at about 84, 13.1, and 2.9%, respectively. Further, it is observed that the C/O and C/N ratios are 6.4% and 28.9% respectively. The core spectra of C1s (Fig. 3b) showed the peak at ∼284.39, ∼286.54, and ∼288.04 eV, respectively about the C=C, =C−OH, and C=O groups along with sp2 hybridization. Additionally, the peak observed at 285.04 eV is due to the presence of C−N bond connectivity [33]. The core spectra of N1s (Fig. 3c) corresponded to the peak at ∼399.01, and ∼399.96 eV related to the pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N, respectively. Further, the peaks at ∼403.96 and ∼401.56 eV are related to the pyridine N-oxide and graphitic-N, respectively [34–35]. . Furthermore, the O1s spectrum (Fig. 3d) showed two peaks sat ∼532.01and ∼533.81 eV confirmed the O=C−OH and C=O oxygen functionalities, respectively [35,36]. The obtained XPS results confirmed the nitrogen atoms contained with the carbon and oxygen in the C-750 sample. The existence of nitrogen along with the carbon structure effectively promotes electrical conductivity, which is also evidenced in the electrochemical analysis of the C-750 sample. 3.2 HRTEM and Morphological analysis The high-resolution-transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) images of C-450 are presented in Fig. 4 . The as-synthesized C-450 showed a thick sheet-like structure that contains bunches of carbon sheets (Fig. 4a). Further, the magnification image of C-450 also confirmed the sheet-like structures of carbon in the sample. (Fig. 4b). However, HRTEM analysis of C-450 revealed the thick and compact carbon sheets with no porous nature (Fig. 4c). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern showed (Fig. 4d) the bright ring formation which confirmed that the C-450 is in polycrystalline nature. However, the TEM and HRTEM images of the C-750 sample showed contrasting morphology as presented in Fig. 5 . The TEM images of C-750 (Fig. 5a,b) showed thin sheets of carbon nanosheets with a length of around 2 µm. Fig. 5c shows that the obtained carbon possesses porous nature, in contrast to the C-450 sample. This indicates that KOH treatment effectively supported the formation of hierarchical porous carbons of C-750 (Fig. 5c). Further, it is confirmed that the C-750 sample revealed rich interconnected microporous structures on the surface which form tunnel-like channels. KOH treatment helps to thin the carbon sheets by increasing the interlayer spacing of the carbon during the activation process. [37]. The SAED pattern of C-750 (Fig. 5d) showed a ring pattern that confirms the polycrystalline nature, and the results are well agreed with the XRD. The TEM and HRTEM analyses of C-750 confirmed that the structure is effectively varied due to the KOH activation process. The morphology of the C-450 and C-750 samples was recorded using FESEM and are presented in Fig. 6. The morphology of C-450 (Fig. 6a) revealed the layered structure and these layers are combined and then formed the bunches of carbon layer structures. Fig. 6b showed that the morphology of the C-750 is a thin layer structure when compared with that of the C-450. Thus, the KOH activation in the C-750 sample has effectively modified the morphology and exfoliated the carbon sheet, and formed defective sides on the carbon sheets. Further, the energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDAX) (Fig. 6c) confirmed the presence of C, N, and O in the C-750 sample which indicated no other impurities occurred in the C-750 sample. 3.3 Brunauer-Emmett-Teller(BET) surface area analysis The textural properties of the C-750 sample were obtained from nitrogen adsorption and desorption measurement. The C-750 sample revealed (Fig. 7 a) the type-I isotherm which shows a plateau at partial pressure at p/po< 0.4 which confirmed the occurrence of small porous in the C-750. Then narrow hysteresis loop is observed in the range of p/po= 0.4–0.9 which confirmed the presence of large porous in the C-750 sample. In the present investigation, the C-750 sample revealed a BET surface area of 3551.07 m²/g. Further, the pore size and pore volume of the C-750 sample was obtained from Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Fig. 7b showed the BJH model of C-750 which possessed a sharp peak at 3.70 nm and a wide peak at 9.91 nm confirming the presence of a mesoporous structure in the C-750. The C-750 sample possessed a pore volume of about 0.511 cc/g. Further, BET analysis was carried out for the sample of NDBC which shows the surface area, pore size, and pore volume was 1560 m2/g, 7.71 nm, and 0.315 cc/g respectively (Fig. 7c). The mesoporous structure that occurred in the C-750 might be due to the biomass source along with the hydrogen bonding, van der Waals forces, and dipolar ionic interactions. Further, KOH has effectively enhanced the activation process by etching the carbon into gaseous products which created the enormous micro- and mesopores structures and also together the functional groups on the surface of C-750 [38]. The C-750 sample showed an enhancement of the surface area of about 3551.07 m²/g and a mesoporous (3.70 nm and 9.91 nm) nature which aided in improving the electrochemical performance of the prepared materials. 3.4 Electrochemical behavior of activated carbon Initially, a three-electrode system is carried out to analyze the electrochemical performance of the as-synthesized carbon materials BC, NDBC, C-450, and C-750 using KOH (6 M) as an electrolyte. The electrochemical properties such as cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) were analyzed in the operating potential window of −0.9 V to 0 V (vs.AgCl). The CV and GCD plots of BC and NDBC were analyzed and the results are presented in Fig. 8 . The BC and NDBC carbon particles showed a typical rectangular shape of voltammogram confirming the EDLC characteristics (Fig. 8a,b). In addition, the NDBC also showed an enhancement of the voltammogram current and area than that of BC with increased current concerning the increased scan rate (Fig. 8c). The high scan rate possesses more diffusion rate. Thereby more electrolytic ions reach the interface between the electrode and electrolyte whereas very few ions only participate in the charge transfer reaction. Hence, the current is gradually increasing with an increase in the scan rate. Further, the small peaks appeared around −0.4 V (vs Ag/AgCl) might be due to the reversible redox reaction that occurred from the oxygen functional groups on the carbon. The BC exhibited a linear GCD curve and possessed a low specific capacitance of 39.33, 26.22, 21.33, 17.77, and 16.11 Fg−1 at a current density of 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 Ag−1, respectively (Fig. 8d). The GCD plot of NDBC (Fig. 8e) showed an enhancement in the specific capacitance of 119.6, 82, 92.44, 78.81 and 76.29 Fg−1 at the current density of 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 Ag−1, respectively. The CV and GCD plots of C-450 and C-750 are presented in Fig. 9 . The CV analysis of the C-450 electrode was carried out at different scan rate values from 5, 10, 20, 50, 100, and 200 mV/s, and the obtained CV curves are shown in Fig. 9a. The CV curves of C-450 revealed the poor rectangular shape of the voltammogram. This might be due to the C-450 sample containing a thick layer of carbon sheets, thus providing poor electrochemical activity. On the other hand, the C-750 sample revealed a perfect rectangular shape of the voltammogram at different scans of 5, 10, 20, 50, 100, and 200 mV/s which confirmed the ideal EDLC behavior (Fig. 9b). This might be due to the KOH activation, porous nature of the carbon and nitrogen atom implanted on the carbon surface as evidenced by FTIR (Fig. 2b), XPS (Fig. 3) and EDAX (Fig. 6c) results. Further, the small peaks that appeared around −0.4 V (vs Ag/AgCl) might be due to the reversible redox reaction of oxygen functional groups on the carbon. The C-750 exhibited a higher capacitance value compared to the C-450 sample. Thus, it is evident that the high surface area and mesoporous pore architecture of the C-750 efficiently increased the charge storage capacitance. The voltammograms of C-750 showed the increased current with increased scan rate (Fig. 9c). The obtained results evidenced that the C-750 shows rectangular feature remains stable even on higher scan rates, which confirms the superior capability and reversibility in the case of C-750. The adsorption-desorption properties of C-750 are analyzed, which confirmed the non-Faradaic nature due to the presence of porous structure on the carbon surface [39,40]. The C-450 exhibited specific capacitance of 19.4, 15.77, 10.6, 6.66, 5.8, and 5.55 Fg−1 at a current density of1, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 Ag−1, respectively (Fig. 9d). Further, the charge-discharge profiles of C-750 was evaluated at a different current density from 1 to 10 Ag−1 (Fig. 9e). The specific capacitance of C-750 at different scanning rates are found to be 354.44, 295.55, 282.22, 268, 251.55 and 245.55 Fg−1, respectively. The C-750 electrode (Fig. 9e) showed slightly non-linear behavior concerning time which exhibited two plateaus lines related to the charging and discharging process owing to the presence of carbon along with heteroatoms such as N, and O [41]. Further, C-750 exhibited an enhancement in the specific capacitance of 354.44 Fg−1 at the current density of about 1 Ag−1 which is higher than that of the other samples (BC, NDBC, C-450). This remarkable enhancement of the specific capacitance in C-750 is due to the presence of high surface area, mesopores, and facile electrode kinetics. Further, the specific capacitance of the C-750 is decreased from 354.44 to 245.55 Fg−1 by increasing the current density (from 1 to 10 Ag−1) probably due to the pulverization of active materials at a high current density [23,42]. The charge-discharge analysis reveals that the C-750 could deliver enhanced specific capacitance. Therefore, we further investigate the stability of C-750 for the cycle number. The C-750 and NDBC were used for the GCD cyclic stability for 1000 cycles and the results are presented in Fig. 10 a. The cycle stability of NDBC showed the specific capacitance in the first cycle is 82 Fg−1 (2 Ag−1) and the same specific capacitance is well maintained up to 1000 cycles with no loss, which confirmed the better stability of the material. The C-750 sample showed a specific capacitance of 251.55 Fg−1 at the current density of 6 Ag−1 in the first cycle and the same specific capacitance is maintained up to 1000 cycles; which confirmed that the C-750 showed better stability. Further, the Nyquist plots were plotted and compared in the frequency of 10 mHz - 10 KHz for the samples of C-450, C-750, and cycled C-750 and are presented in Fig. 10b. The Nyquist plots revealed the semicircles at high, and middle-frequency regions and a linear slope observed at the low-frequency region related to the solution resistance (Rs ), charge transfer resistance (Rct ), and diffusion kinetics respectively. Further, closer observation (Fig. 10c) revealed the impedance spectra of both C-750 and 1000 cycled C-750 are indistinguishable and there is no change in the Rct value (0.1 Ω) which confirmed the stability of the C-750 sample even after 1000 cycles. Whereas, the C-450 sample exhibited a relatively high charge transfer resistance of about 3 Ω than that of C-750 (0.1Ω). The BC, NDBC and cycled NDBC (Fig. 10d) showed a relatively higher Rct than that of C-750. In the present investigation, it is observed that the C-750 effectively conducts high charge carriers than the other prepared samples. Therefore, the present result suggests that the C-750 material is more suitable for energy storage applications. To fabricate the symmetric supercapacitor, it is important to analyze the CV, GCD, and EIS of C-750 in the positive potential window of 0 to 0.5 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) (Fig. 11 ). The CV is carried out at different scan rates (5, 10, 20, 40, 100 and 200 mV/s) which confirmed better rate capability (Fig. 11a). The GCD plots of C-750 are presented in Fig. 11b which showed the specific capacitance of about 184.8, 148, 91.2, 64.8, 45, 40.8 Fg−1 at a scan rate of 1, 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 Ag−1, respectively. Further, Fig. 11c revealed that in the EIS analysis of the C-750, the Rct is about 50 Ohms. To fabricate the two-electrode system, the mass balance is calculated from the relation, mass balance is calculated for both positive and negative potential from the relation [25], M + M − = C − Δ V − C + Δ V + ; where, M+ and M- are the mass of the positive and negative electrodes, respectively. C+ and C- are the specific capacitance of the positive and negative electrodes, respectively. ∆V+ and ∆V- are the positive and negative potential (vs. Ag/AgCl), respectively. The C-750- based symmetric supercapacitor was analyzed in a two-electrode system using 6 M KOH as an electrolyte solution. Fig. 12 a showed the CV curve of C-750 at different scan rates from 5 to 200 mV/s which exhibited the quasi-rectangular shape of the voltammogram represented the EDLC behavior. The CV curve of C-750 is stable even at a high scan rate which confirmed that the porous carbon nanosheets are suitable material for rapid ion transfer. Further, the GCD plot of C-750 at various current densities from 1 to 5 Ag−1 were recorded and are presented in Fig. 12b which exhibited the near triangle shape and confirmed the desirable capacitive and electrochemical reversibility. Further, the C-750 (Fig. 12c) showed that the specific capacitance of 132.75, 109.5, 90.72, 77, and 67.5 Fg−1 at different current densities of 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 Ag−1, respectively. From the Ragone plot shown in Fig. 12d, the energy density and power density values of the C-750 sample are found to be 47.2, 38.93, 32.25, 27.37, and 24 Whkg−1; and 3200, 6399, 9595, 12,796, and 16,000 Wkg−1. The electrochemical results suggested the C-750 effectively enhanced the energy density of about 47.2 Whkg−1 and power density of about 16,000 Wkg−1. Fig. 13 a showed the cycle life study of the C-750 electrode for 1000 cycles at a current density of 2 Ag−1. The specific capacitance of the C-750 sample in the first cycle is calculated to be 109.5 Fg−1 which gradually decreased to 100 Fg−1 for 1000 cycles which confirmed the 91% retention rate in the specific capacitance values. The Nyquist plot of before and after 1000 cycled C-750 in a symmetrical two-electrode system is presented in Fig. 13b. The charge transfer resistance (Rct ) of before and after cycling (1000 cycles) of the C-750 sample shown in Fig. 13c exhibited 8.5 Ω. The EIS analysis confirmed that the C-750 revealed better stability in the two-electrode system. Further, the performance of the C-750 sample is compared with the previous reports and it is observed that the C-750 surpassed the previous reports (Table 1 ). As mentioned above, the C-750 sample revealed a high BET surface area of about 3551.07 m2/g which was supported by increased specific capacitance value (354.44 Fg−1) when compared with the other prepared carbon materials (BC, NDBC, C-450). Further, the energy and power density of C-750 material is found to be 47.2 Whkg−1 and 16,000 Wkg−1, respectively. 4 Conclusion In the present investigation, the simple and cost-effective high-surface porous carbon nanosheets were synthesized from Acorus Calamus for the first time for the high-performance supercapacitor application. The XRD analysis of C-750 revealed the high crystalline nature of the sample compared to the other prepared samples. Further, the Raman analysis of C-450 and C-750 showed the ID/IG ratio of 0.71 and 1.04 which confirmed the carbon sheets were effectively exfoliated in C-750 and possessed an enormous surface area. The BET analysis revealed the surface area of C-750 with the surface area, pore size, and pore volume of 3551. 07 m2/g, 3.70 nm, and 0.51 cc/g, respectively. The morphology of the C-450 sample showed a thick layer of carbon sheets whereas the C-750 showed a thin layer of carbon sheets along with porous structures. The XPS survey spectrum confirmed the presence of 2.9% of nitrogen atoms implanted on the C-750 sample. The TEM images of C-750 revealed the 2 µm length of carbon nanosheets along with a few-layer thickness and the SAED pattern confirmed the polycrystalline nature of the samples. The CV curve of C-750 possessed a rectangular shape of the voltammogram which revealed the ideal electrochemical double-layer capacitance. The GCD analysis revealed the C-450 showed a lower specific capacitance of about 9.4 Fg−1 at a current density of1 Ag−1; whereas the C-750 electrode exhibited a high specific capacitance of 354.44 Fg−1 at a current density of 1 Ag−1 which was about 37 times higher than that of the corresponding C-450 sample. The impedance spectra of C-450 and C-750 exhibited Rct of about 3 Ω and 0.1 Ω, respectively. It is important to note in the present investigation, the impedance spectra of both C-750 and cycled C-750 were indistinguishable and there was no change in the Rct value (0.1 Ω) which confirmed that C-750 had better stability and charge carrier ability even after 1000 cycles. Additionally, the two-electrode system showed a retained specific capacitance of about 91% after 1000 cycles for the C-750 sample. Further, the energy density and power density of C-750 were found to be 47.2 Whkg−1 and 16,000 Wkg−1, respectively. The obtained results revealed that the high surface area along with the mesoporous nature of carbon particles opened a new prospect in the fabrication of carbon-based electrode materials in the field of energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: Modern society's biggest challenges are affordable, clean energy production and storage. Thus, recent research aims at the discovery of novel electrode materials for enhanced energy production and storage. Herein, nitrogen-implanted carbon particles were synthesized for the first time from the Acorus Calamus for the symmetric supercapacitor application. The KOH-activated carbon particles at 750 °C (C-750) under a nitrogen atmosphere revealed the better structural, textural, morphological, and electrochemical performance. The BET analysis confirmed that the C-750 carbon nanoparticles tremendously enhanced the surface area of about 3551.07 m2/g. Further, the pore size and pore volume were obtained from BJH analysis that showed 3.70 nm and 0.51 cc/g, respectively. The high surface area along with the mesoporous nature of the C-750 sample effectively enhanced the specific capacitance to 354.44 Fg−1 at 1 Ag−1 using a 6 M KOH electrolytic solution. Further, the enhancement of energy and power density of the C-750 was observed at about 47.2 Whkg−1 and 16,000 Wkg−1, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Nitrogen implanted carbon nanosheets derived from Acorus calamus as an efficient electrode for the supercapacitor application
